DOCNAME: CASE OF VITO SANTE SANTORO v. ITALY
CONCLUSION: Violation of P4-2;Violation of P1-3;Pecuniary damage - claim dismissed;Non-pecuniary damage - financial award;Costs and expenses partial award - domestic proceedings;Costs and expenses partial award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE ( province of GPE ) .
CARDINAL . In an order of DATE , filed with the registry on DATE , ORG imposed a preventive measure on the applicant , who was placed under special police supervision for DATE .

CARDINAL . ORG found that numerous criminal complaints had been made against the applicant . In particular , it found that in DATE and DATE a series of criminal complaints had been lodged alleging that he had received stolen goods under cover of his vehicle dismantling and spare parts business . On CARDINAL DATE a preventive measure in the form of a warning ( avviso sociale ) was imposed on the applicant for DATE . On DATE a criminal complaint was lodged against him for aiding and abetting theft and trading in stolen goods ; he was acquitted by a judgment of DATE . On CARDINAL DATE the applicant was arrested with CARDINAL others in connection with another complaint for receiving stolen goods which had been lodged against him . In the light of the foregoing , ORG considered that there were reasonable grounds for believing that , in spite of his clean record , the applicant was a habitual offender and thus “ socially dangerous ” , within the meaning of CARDINAL of PERSON no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL of CARDINAL DATE . It refused , however , to make a compulsory residence order ( obbligo di soggiorno ) against him .
CARDINAL . NORP The order imposing the preventive measure was forwarded for enforcement to the Brindisi prefect on DATE and served on the applicant on CARDINAL DATE .
CARDINAL . The applicant appealed , but his appeal was dismissed by ORG on DATE . The order became final on DATE and was subsequently served on the GPE municipality on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the GPE police drafted , in the applicant ’s presence , a document setting out the obligations imposed on him ( verbale di sottoposizione agli obblighi ) .
CARDINAL . The applicant was required :
( a ) to look for a suitable job within DATE from the date of service of the order ;
( b ) not to change his place of residence ;
( c ) not to leave his home without informing the authorities responsible for supervising him ;
( d ) to live an honest life and not to arouse suspicion ;
( e ) not to associate with persons who had a criminal record or who were subject to preventive or security measures ;

( f ) not to return home TIME in DATE and TIME in DATE or to leave home before TIME , unless due cause could be shown and in all cases only after informing the authorities responsible for supervising him ;
( g ) not to keep or carry weapons ;
( h ) not to go to bars or attend public meetings ;
( i ) to report to the relevant police station on DATE TIME ;
( j ) to have on him at all times the card setting out his precise obligations under the preventive measure and a copy of the court order .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant applied to ORG for a declaration that the preventive measure had expired on DATE , that is , DATE after the date on which the order of CARDINAL DATE was served on him .

CARDINAL . In an order of DATE , ORG found that , even if pursuant to LAW no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL the special supervision period began on DATE on which the person on whom the preventive measure was imposed was served with the relevant order , compliance with that formality was necessary but not sufficient to constitute an initial step in the implementation of the measure . For there to be such an initial step , it was also necessary under LAW no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL for the relevant order to be forwarded for enforcement to the competent police authority . ORG observed that , under ORG case - law , special supervision did not lapse at the end of the period for which it had been imposed , independently of when it was implemented . In the case before it , the initial step in the implementation of the measure had been taken on DATE , DATE on which the GPE police had drafted the document setting out the obligations imposed on the applicant . Consequently , it held that the preventive measure had not ceased to apply .

CARDINAL . The applicant appealed to ORG . He maintained that the preventive measure had automatically ceased to apply on DATE or , at the latest , on DATE , which was DATE after the date on which the order had been served on the Brindisi police and the GPE municipality . In any event , the applicant sought an order discharging the measure , arguing that there were no grounds for it to remain in force .

CARDINAL . In a judgment of DATE , ORG upheld the order of DATE , observing that the case fell outside those for which statute provided the automatic lapse of special supervision . It considered that the preventive measure could not automatically cease to apply on the date stated in the order of CARDINAL DATE independently of when it was implemented . Consequently , it concluded that the starting - point for the application of the preventive measure was DATE on which the first steps had been taken to implement it . In this case that had been DATE , when the police had drafted the document setting out the applicant ’s obligations under the order .
CARDINAL . The applicant appealed on points of law to ORG .

CARDINAL . In a judgment of DATE , which was filed with the registry on DATE , ORG ruled that the order for special supervision of the applicant had ceased to apply on DATE . It observed that LAW no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL expressly provided that the period of special supervision started to run on DATE the person to be supervised was served with the relevant order . Consequently , contrary to the opinion of ORG , it found that the date on which the document setting out the obligations imposed on the applicant was drafted was not relevant for the purposes of identifying the date on which the preventive measure first took effect . It concluded that the period of special supervision had started to run on DATE on which the relevant order was served on the applicant ( DATE ) .
CARDINAL . In the meantime , on DATE the GPE police had informed ORG that the order for special supervision of the applicant had ceased to apply on DATE .

CARDINAL . As a result of the special supervision measure imposed on the applicant , ORG decided on DATE to strike the applicant off the electoral register on the ground that his civic rights had been suspended pursuant to Presidential Decree no . CARDINAL of DATE .
CARDINAL . NORP The applicant was subsequently prevented from taking part in the regional council ( PERSON ) election of DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant ’s name was restored to the electoral register .

CARDINAL . In a certificate issued on CARDINAL DATE , however , the mayor of GPE stated that the applicant had been subject to a further DATE ’s special supervision by a decision of the Brindisi police of DATE . On DATE the mayor declared that the applicant would be struck off the electoral register for DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG refused the applicant ’s request to be allowed to take part in the national parliamentary election on DATE .

CARDINAL . The applicant lodged an appeal with ORG in which he contended that the preventive measure had ceased to apply on DATE and that , accordingly , there were no grounds for excluding him from the election .
CARDINAL . In a judgment of DATE , ORG dismissed the appeal on the ground that the disenfranchisement could be challenged only after the preventive measure had actually been implemented .

CARDINAL . The power to impose preventive measures was introduced by PERSON no . CARDINAL of DATE . Such measures are intended to prevent individuals who are considered “ socially dangerous ” from committing offences . The statute indicates CARDINAL groups of socially dangerous persons : ( a ) anyone who , on the basis of factual evidence , must be regarded as a habitual offender ; ( b ) anyone who , on account of his conduct or lifestyle and on the basis of factual evidence , must be regarded as habitually deriving his income from the proceeds of crime ; and ( c ) anyone who , on account of his conduct and on the basis of factual evidence , must be regarded as having committed offences endangering the physical or mental integrity of minors or posing a threat to society , security or public order .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of Law no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL provides that persons who are socially dangerous may be placed under special police supervision . The competent court sits in camera and must give a reasoned decision after hearing the public prosecutor and the person concerned , who has the right to file memorials and to be represented by a lawyer . Both parties may lodge an appeal and/or an appeal on points of law , which have no suspensive effect .

CARDINAL . When imposing a preventive measure , the court must fix its duration and specify the conditions with which the person concerned must comply . In accordance with paragraph CARDINAL of LAW of PERSON no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , the special supervision period starts to run on DATE on which its addressee is notified of the relevant order and automatically ends when the period of time fixed in the order has elapsed .
CARDINAL . LAW no . CARDINAL of DATE provides that , inter alia , persons on whom preventive measures have been imposed by a court order or an administrative decision shall be disenfranchised .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of that decree provides that in such cases the prefect ( questore ) empowered to enforce such measures shall notify the municipality where the person concerned resides of any decision entailing the loss of civic rights . ORG shall then remove the name of the person concerned from the electoral register , even outside one of the usual periods for updating the lists .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of the LAW confers legislative power on the regions . It sets out the competence of the regions , inter alia , for regional administrative planning , local policy , public health , education , local museums and libraries , town planning , tourism , traffic regulations , navigation , quarries and peat bogs , hunting , agriculture , forests and handicraft . Article CARDINAL also states that the regions have legislative power in other matters established by constitutional laws . Regional laws are enacted by the regional councils ( LAW ) .
